question: 渡す
sourceMnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transit</kanji>, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are transiting one object over to another person (the word is <vocabulary>to hand over</vocabulary>), though, so it kind of makes sense. You see the <ja>す</ja>? You're <reading>su</reading>ing somebody, so you hand over the papers telling them you're suing them. Don't confuse this with <ja>渡る</ja> which is "to cross over." <ja>す</ja> is sue.
sourceReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
